sections.title: How Benefits Are Calculated
sections.content: Your Social Security benefit is based on your highest 35 years of earnings, adjusted for inflation. The full retirement age (FRA) is currently 66-67 depending on your birth year. You can claim as early as age 62 (with reduced benefits) or delay until age 70 (with increased benefits).

points.title: Early Claiming (Age 62)
points.description: Reduces benefits by up to 30% but provides income earlier in retirement.

points.title: Delayed Claiming (Age 70)
points.description: Increases benefits by 8% per year beyond FRA, maxing out at age 70.

sections.title: Delaying Often Pays Off
sections.content: For most people, delaying Social Security until age 70 provides the highest lifetime benefit, especially if you expect to live into your 80s or beyond.

sections.title: Spousal and Survivor Benefits
sections.content: Spouses can claim based on their own work record or up to 50% of their spouse's benefit. Survivor benefits can be up to 100% of the deceased spouse's benefit. Coordinating claiming strategies between spouses can significantly increase household benefits.

sections.title: Plan Your Social Security Strategy
steps: Create a my Social Security account to view your benefit estimates
Consider your health, family longevity, and other income sources when choosing claiming age
If married, evaluate spousal benefit options and coordinate with your spouse
Factor Social Security into your overall retirement income plan

sections.title: Break-Even Analysis
sections.content: Calculate the break-even age where delaying benefits becomes more beneficial than claiming early. For most people, this occurs around age 78-82.
